title: 107_hr1823
content:
The "Guadalupe-Hidalgo Treaty Land Claims Act of 2001" establishes a Commission to examine land claims, provide assistance, and report findings. It includes definitions, membership details, miscellaneous powers, and authorization of appropriations. The "Guadalupe-Hidalgo Treaty Land Claims Act of 2001" defines key terms such as Commission, Treaty of Guadalupe-Hidalgo, and eligible descendant. It outlines criteria for eligible descendants related to Mexican citizenship, community land grants, and becoming a US citizen post-treaty. The "Guadalupe-Hidalgo Treaty Land Claims Act of 2001" defines terms like community land grant as land held in common by families under a grant from Spain or Mexico before specific dates. "Reconstituted" refers to restoring a valid community land grant to full municipality status. Congress finds that the western and southwestern United States has a unique history with Spanish and Mexican land grants, some provisions of the Treaty of Guadalupe-Hidalgo have not been fully implemented, and there are questions about land ownership in several states. Certain public lands in western and southwestern states still exist, and Congress has used land claim commissions to examine disputed land possession questions in the past. The Guadalupe-Hidalgo Treaty Land Claims Commission is established with seven members appointed by the President, including eligible descendants and a member of an Indian tribe. Members serve for the life of the Commission and receive compensation at the level V of the Executive Schedule. SEC. 4. EXAMINATION OF LAND CLAIMS. (a) Eligible descendants can file a petition with the Commission seeking validation of a community land grant claim. 
(b) The petition must be submitted within five years of the enactment of the Act. 
(c) The petition must include names and addresses of petitioners and confirm the land was a community land grant at the time of the Guadalupe-Hidalgo Treaty. The Guadalupe-Hidalgo Treaty requires eligible descendants to file a petition with the Commission to validate a community land grant claim. The petition must include details about the extent of the land grant, residency or intent to settle on the land, and all known facts and documents related to the grant. The Commission will hold a hearing where all interested parties can participate, and it has the power to issue subpoenas. The Commission has the power to issue subpoenas for witnesses and evidence related to petitions submitted under the Guadalupe-Hidalgo Treaty. Failure to comply may result in a court order for testimony or evidence, with penalties for contempt. The Commission has the authority to issue subpoenas for witnesses and evidence related to petitions under the Guadalupe-Hidalgo Treaty. Subpoenas must be served in accordance with the Federal Rules of Civil Procedure. Process for court applications can be served in the person's judicial district. The Commission will determine the validity of community land grants based on petition facts, hearings, and additional information. Recommended relief may be provided in response to a petition. The Commission, under the Guadalupe-Hidalgo Treaty, can recommend relief for valid petitions, including reconstituting community land grants. The decision does not affect non-Federal land ownership rights. The Commission, under the Guadalupe-Hidalgo Treaty, can recommend relief for valid petitions, including reconstituting community land grants by substituting comparable Federal lands in the same State as the non-Federal lands. The Commission will establish a Community Land Grant Study Center in New Mexico to conduct research and investigations. The Comptroller General can provide assistance with personnel and resources from the General Accounting Office. The Commission also has miscellaneous powers. The Commission has the authority to hold hearings, take testimony, administer oaths, accept gifts, use the United States mails, and request administrative support services. Members and agents can take actions authorized by the Commission. The Commission, as an agency of the United States, can request administrative support services from the Administrator of General Services on a reimbursable basis. Additionally, the Commission is granted immunity under part V of title 18, United States Code. The Commission will submit a report to the President and Congress after making decisions, including recommendations on community land grants. The Commission will terminate 180 days after submitting its final report. $1,900,000 is authorized for each fiscal year from 2002 to 2008 for Commission activities and the Community Land Grant Study Center.
